Situation1: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Expectation2: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation2: A file for a straightforward procedural hearing scheduled in two weeks has just been delivered to your chambers for preliminary review.
Story: I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of the afternoon pressing in. The team meeting was about to start—our last chance to voice concerns before the project’s direction was set in stone. As a colleague, I was expected to be present, to contribute, to show my commitment to the team. But just as I was about to join, a courier arrived with a thick envelope: the case file for a procedural hearing I was scheduled to preside over in two weeks. As a judge, I was expected to review every detail thoroughly, to ensure fairness and preparedness, even for cases that seemed routine. The file was marked urgent, flagged for preliminary review today. My phone buzzed with a reminder for the meeting, while the file sat on my desk, demanding my attention. I felt the tension coil in my chest—my team counting on my input, the court system counting on my diligence. I stared at the screen, then at the file, torn between two worlds, each expecting my full presence, each unwilling to wait.
